title: Business News: Corporate Watch
text:
Plant Is Planned

Microsoft Corp. and two energy-related companies plan a power plant in California they say will produce a negative amount of carbon emissions, an example of big companies experimenting with energy projects.

A unit of oil-field-services company Schlumberger Ltd., Chevron Corp. and Microsoft are looking at opening a bioenergy plant in Mendota, Calif., that converts agricultural waste such as almond trees into a gas that, when combined with oxygen, will generate electricity.

Clean Energy Systems, which focuses on deploying energy developments that cut carbon, is also part of the effort, the companies said.

-- Micah Maidenberg

---

TORO

Residential Demand

Fuels Growth

Toro Co. posted a larger first-quarter profit as sales rose, driven by a strong increase in demand from residential customers.

The Bloomington, Minn., maker of turf equipment reported earnings of $111.3 million, compared with $70.1 million in the prior-year quarter. Revenue climbed to $873 million from $767.5 million the year before.

Revenue from the company's residential segment grew by 31% year over year to $217.7 million, as demand for snow equipment and walking power mowers lifted sales to consumers. Chief Executive Richard Olson said he expects strong retail demand for the company's residential products to persist.

Sales to professionals increased 9.3% amid higher sales of lawn mowers used by landscaping contractors. The company's acquisition of Venture Products also contributed to higher professional sales, Toro said.

-- Matt Grossman

---

MONDELEZ

New Recycling

Policy Is Backed

Mondelez International Inc. said it was in favor of a reasonable new federal recycling policy focused in part on the kind of plastic wraps it uses to package its Oreos and a number of its other snacks.

Such flexible films are commonly used by consumer-product manufacturers as packaging, but they aren't easy to reuse once consumers are done with them.

"Flexible plastic films, like the flow wraps we use on our snacks, are still difficult to collect, sort and reprocess economically," Mondelez Impact Chief Christine Montenegro McGrath said.

Under such efforts, governments give manufacturers financial or physical responsibility for treating or disposing of such products after consumers use them and could provide support for such efforts, according to a definition from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Across its portfolio of products, the company has set a goal of cutting its use of virgin plastic by 5% by 2025, assuming a stable portfolio.

-- Micah Maidenberg

---

MICHAELS

Earnings, Sales

Rose in Quarter

Michaels Cos. posted a larger fourth-quarter profit and higher sales year over year, one day after the company said it plans to go private in a leveraged buyout.

The Irving, Texas, chain of art-supply stores logged earnings of $255.1 million, up from $181.7 million in the prior-year period. Revenue climbed to $1.92 billion from $1.72 billion in 2019's fourth quarter.

Comparable-store sales grew by 13%. Michaels finished the quarter with 1,252 stores, down from the 1,274 stores it had 12 months earlier.

On Wednesday, Michaels said it plans to go private in a leveraged buyout by Apollo Global Management Inc. that values Michaels at $3.3 billion. Apollo is offering to buy Michaels for $22 a share.

-- Matt Grossman
